canonical_explanation.text: Geometric patterns use shapes that repeat or grow in a predictable way. A repeating pattern has a group of shapes (the core) that repeats over and over. A growing pattern has shapes that change in a regular way (e.g., one more triangle each time). Symmetry means one half of a figure mirrors the other. A line of symmetry divides a figure into two identical halves.
rules: A repeating pattern has a core unit that repeats (e.g., circle-square-circle-square)
A growing pattern changes in size or number of shapes in a regular way
A line of symmetry divides a shape into two matching halves
Some shapes have more than one line of symmetry
A circle has infinite lines of symmetry
A square has 4 lines of symmetry; a rectangle has 2

questions.question_text: In the pattern: triangle, circle, triangle, circle, triangle, ___. What comes next?
questions.explanation_correct: The core is: triangle, circle (repeating). After triangle comes circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pattern alternates: triangle, circle, triangle, circle. Next = circle.

questions.question_text: Which is a repeating pattern?

options.text: One triangle, two triangles, three triangles

questions.explanation_correct: Circle, square, circle, square has a repeating core of 'circle, square'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A repeating pattern has a core group that repeats. Circle-square repeats.

questions.question_text: How many lines of symmetry does a square have?
questions.explanation_correct: A square has 4 lines of symmetry: 2 through the midpoints of opposite sides and 2 through opposite corners.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A square has 4 lines of symmetry — 2 diagonal and 2 through midpoints of opposite sides.

questions.question_text: A line of symmetry divides a figure into:
questions.explanation_correct: A line of symmetry splits a figure so that one half is the mirror image of the other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Line of symmetry = one half mirrors the other.

questions.question_text: Which of these letters has a line of symmetry: A, B, F, G?
questions.explanation_correct: The letter A has a vertical line of symmetry. B has a horizontal line. F and G do not have lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A has a vertical line of symmetry (left-right halves mirror each other).

questions.question_text: A circle has exactly one line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A circle has infinite (unlimited) lines of symmetry — any diameter is a line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A circle has infinitely many lines of symmetry, not just one.

questions.question_text: In a growing pattern of dots: 1, 3, 5, 7, ___. How many dots come next?
questions.explanation_correct: The pattern adds 2 each time: 7 + 2 = 9.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Growing pattern adds 2 dots each step: 7 + 2 = 9.

questions.question_text: A rectangle has ___ lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has 2 lines of symmetry: one vertical (through the midpoints of the top and bottom sides) and one horizontal (through the midpoints of the left and right sides).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rectangle has 2 lines of symmetry — horizontal and vertical through the centre.

questions.question_text: The pattern core is: red circle, blue square, green triangle. What is the 10th shape?
questions.explanation_correct: Core length = 3. Position 10 ÷ 3 = 3 remainder 1. Remainder 1 means it's the 1st shape in the core = red circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 10 ÷ 3 = 3 R 1. Remainder 1 → 1st shape in core = red circle.

questions.question_text: A tile pattern goes: square, square, triangle, square, square, triangle, ___. The next shape is:
questions.explanation_correct: Core: square, square, triangle (length 3). Position 7: 7÷3 = 2 R 1. The 1st shape in the core = square.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Core is: square, square, triangle. The 7th position starts the core again: square.

questions.question_text: How many lines of symmetry does an equilateral triangle have?
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has 3 lines of symmetry — one from each vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equilateral triangle: all sides equal → 3 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Which shape has exactly 1 line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: An isosceles triangle (two equal sides) has exactly 1 line of symmetry — the one from the vertex angle to the midpoint of the base.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Square has 4, equilateral triangle has 3, circle has infinite. Isosceles triangle has exactly 1.

questions.question_text: Which of these shapes is NOT symmetrical?
questions.explanation_correct: A scalene triangle has all sides and angles different, so it generally has no line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A scalene triangle (no equal sides) typically has no line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: The letter H has a line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: H has both a vertical and a horizontal line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H is symmetrical — it has a vertical line and a horizontal line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: In a growing pattern, the number of matchsticks used is: 4, 7, 10, 13. How many are used in the 5th figure?
questions.explanation_correct: Rule: +3. 5th figure = 13 + 3 = 16 matchsticks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each step adds 3 matchsticks: 13 + 3 = 16.

questions.question_text: How many lines of symmetry does a regular hexagon have?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular hexagon has 6 lines of symmetry: 3 through opposite vertices and 3 through midpoints of opposite sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular hexagon (6 equal sides) has 6 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: A pattern uses triangles: Figure 1 has 1 triangle, Figure 2 has 3 triangles, Figure 3 has 5 triangles. Figure 6 has:
questions.explanation_correct: Pattern: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11. Rule: +2. Figure 6 = 11 triangles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each figure adds 2 triangles: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11. Figure 6 = 11.

questions.question_text: The core of a pattern has 4 shapes. The 25th shape in the pattern is the same as the ___ shape.
questions.explanation_correct: 25 ÷ 4 = 6 remainder 1. Remainder 1 means it's the 1st shape in the core.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 25 ÷ 4 = 6 R 1. Position 1 in the core.

questions.question_text: A regular pentagon has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry. Regular pentagon (5 sides) → 5 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Regular n-gon has n lines of symmetry. Pentagon: n=5 → 5 lines.

questions.question_text: Which of these has NO line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A parallelogram that is not a rectangle has no line of symmetry (though it has rotational symmetry).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A non-rectangular parallelogram has no lines of symmetry. The others all do.

questions.question_text: Which pattern is a growing pattern?
questions.explanation_correct: 1 dot, 2 dots, 3 dots, 4 dots — the number of dots grows by 1 each time. This is a growing pattern.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a growing pattern, the quantity changes in a regular way. Increasing dots = growing pattern.

questions.question_text: A line of symmetry can be horizontal, vertical, or diagonal.
questions.explanation_correct: Lines of symmetry can go in any direction. For example, a square has vertical, horizontal, and two diagonal lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lines of symmetry can be in any orientation — vertical, horizontal, or diagonal.

questions.question_text: The number 8 has:
questions.explanation_correct: The digit 8 has a vertical line of symmetry and a horizontal line of symmetry — total 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 8 is symmetric both vertically and horizontally: 2 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Matchstick squares in a row: Figure 1 uses 4, Figure 2 uses 7, Figure 3 uses 10. Figure 5 uses:
questions.explanation_correct: Rule: +3 per figure. 4, 7, 10, 13, 16. Figure 5 = 16.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each figure adds 3 matchsticks: 4, 7, 10, 13, 16. Figure 5 = 16.

questions.question_text: An equilateral triangle has ___ lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has 3 lines of symmetry — one from each vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equilateral triangle: 3 equal sides, 3 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Which letter has exactly 2 lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: H has a vertical and a horizontal line of symmetry (2 total). A has only 1 (vertical). B has 1 (horizontal). E has 1 (horizontal).
questions.explanation_incorrect: H has both vertical and horizontal symmetry = 2 lines. A, B, E each have only 1.

questions.question_text: A repeating pattern has core: star, heart, diamond. What is the 20th shape?
questions.explanation_correct: Core length = 3. 20 ÷ 3 = 6 remainder 2. 2nd shape in core = heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 20 mod 3 = 2. Second shape in core = heart.

questions.question_text: Which shape has the MOST lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: Circle has infinite lines of symmetry (every diameter). Hexagon has 6, square has 4, rectangle has 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Circle has unlimited lines of symmetry. It has the most among all shapes.

questions.question_text: A growing pattern of squares: Figure 1 has 1×1=1 square, Figure 2 has 2×2=4 squares, Figure 3 has 3×3=9 squares. Figure 5 has:
questions.explanation_correct: Pattern is n². Figure 5 = 5² = 25.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each figure has n² squares. Figure 5: 5×5 = 25.

questions.question_text: A scalene triangle has at least one line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A scalene triangle has all different side lengths and angles, so it has no line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scalene triangle: no equal sides → no line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: In a repeating pattern, the same group of shapes appears again and again.
questions.explanation_correct: A repeating pattern has a core unit that repeats continuously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Repeating pattern = same core group of shapes over and over.

questions.question_text: A shape that looks the same when folded along a line has:
questions.explanation_correct: If folding a shape along a line makes both halves match exactly, that line is a line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Folding along a line and getting matching halves = line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Which of these digits has a horizontal line of symmetry: 0, 3, 8?
questions.explanation_correct: 0 has horizontal symmetry (top mirrors bottom). 3 has horizontal symmetry. 8 has horizontal symmetry. All three have it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0, 3, and 8 all look the same when flipped horizontally.

questions.question_text: In a growing pattern of triangles: 2, 4, 6, 8. The next figure has ___ triangles.
questions.explanation_correct: Rule: +2. Next = 8 + 2 = 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adding 2 each time: 8 + 2 = 10.

questions.question_text: A rhombus has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A rhombus has 2 lines of symmetry — both diagonals are lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rhombus has 2 lines of symmetry along its two diagonals.

questions.question_text: A border pattern repeats every 5 tiles. What position does the 43rd tile match?
questions.explanation_correct: 43 ÷ 5 = 8 remainder 3. The 43rd tile matches the 3rd position in the core.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 43 mod 5 = 3. Matches the 3rd tile in the core.

questions.question_text: Which of these shapes has exactly 5 lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular pentagon has 5 lines of symmetry (one for each vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular n-gon has n lines of symmetry. Pentagon (n=5) → 5 lines.

questions.question_text: A rectangle has 4 lines of symmetry, just like a square.
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has only 2 lines of symmetry (vertical and horizontal through centre). A square has 4 (including two diagonals).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rectangle has 2 lines of symmetry. Square has 4. They are different.

questions.question_text: A pattern uses dots: Figure 1 has 1 dot, Figure 2 has 4 dots, Figure 3 has 9 dots, Figure 4 has 16 dots. These are:
questions.explanation_correct: 1, 4, 9, 16 are 1², 2², 3², 4² — perfect squares.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1=1², 4=2², 9=3², 16=4². These are square numbers (perfect squares).

questions.question_text: The letter O (shaped like a circle) has:
questions.explanation_correct: O is circular in shape. A circle has infinite (unlimited) lines of symmetry — every diameter is a line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: O is approximately a circle, which has infinitely many lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: The core of the pattern: sun, moon, star, sun, moon, star, sun has ___ shapes.
questions.explanation_correct: The core is: sun, moon, star — 3 shapes that repeat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Core = sun, moon, star. Length = 3.

questions.question_text: A regular octagon (8 sides) has ___ lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A regular n-gon has n lines of symmetry. Octagon (n=8) → 8 lines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry: 8 sides → 8 lines.

questions.question_text: If you fold a shape along its line of symmetry, the two halves:
questions.explanation_correct: Folding along a line of symmetry makes the two halves overlap perfectly — they match exactly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By definition, folding along a line of symmetry makes the two halves coincide exactly.

questions.question_text: A pattern of L-shapes is made with matchsticks: Figure 1 uses 2, Figure 2 uses 4, Figure 3 uses 6. Figure 8 uses:
questions.explanation_correct: Rule: each figure uses 2n matchsticks. Figure 8 = 2 × 8 = 16.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pattern: 2n matchsticks. Figure 8: 2 × 8 = 16.

questions.question_text: Which of these has 0 lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A scalene triangle has all different sides and angles — no line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scalene triangle: no equal sides → 0 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: The letter Z has a line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: Z does not have a line of symmetry. You cannot fold it along any line to get matching halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Z has no line of symmetry — no fold line creates matching halves.

questions.question_text: A rangoli pattern repeats its design every 6 sections. If there are 50 sections, how many complete repetitions are there?
questions.explanation_correct: 50 ÷ 6 = 8 remainder 2. There are 8 complete repetitions (with 2 sections left over).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 50 ÷ 6 = 8 R 2. Eight complete repetitions.

questions.question_text: An isosceles trapezium has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: An isosceles trapezium has 1 line of symmetry — the perpendicular bisector of the two parallel sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isosceles trapezium: 1 vertical line of symmetry through the midpoints of the parallel sides.

questions.question_text: In a growing pattern where each figure adds 5 more dots, if Figure 1 has 3 dots, Figure 7 has ___ dots.
questions.explanation_correct: Figure n has 3 + (n-1)×5 dots. Figure 7 = 3 + 6×5 = 3 + 30 = 33.

questions.question_text: Which group of letters ALL have at least one line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A (vertical), M (vertical), T (vertical), X (vertical and horizontal) — all four have at least one line of symmetry. The other groups contain letters without any line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A, M, T, X all have symmetry. F, G, P, Q, R, S, J, K, L, N do not have lines of symmetry.
